justification: The article notes that “experiments showing that even those who profess antiracist beliefs find it harder to associate positive words with black faces compared to white faces (the ‘implicit association test’; Greenwald, McGhee & Schwartz, 1998…)” thereby identifying the IAT as the tool for measuring implicit bias.

In discussing the Wason card-selection problem, the authors state that participants’ tendency to turn over evidentially irrelevant cards “can be taken as an example of confirmation bias,” indicating that the Wason Selection Task is used to detect confirmation bias.

The text introduces the Linda vignette and explains that choosing the more specific option “violates the rule of probability… This error is known as the conjunction fallacy,” showing the Linda Problem is employed to measure susceptibility to the conjunction fallacy.

When describing the subscription-choice experiment, the authors write, “The Decoy Effect is that adding a third option… can alter these preferences,” using this decoy choice setup as the experimental measure of the decoy effect.

topic_or_construct: implicit racial bias in threat perception
justification: The paper refers to “differential likelihood of falsely identifying a young man as carrying a weapon if he is black rather than white (Correll et al., 2002),” a study that employs the shooter task known as the Police Officer’s Dilemma to assess implicit racial bias in threat perception.
